title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON – In the annals of the NBA, some victories are etched into history not by the final score, but by the superhuman effort of one man. Thursday night was one such occasion, as Hakeem Olajuwon authored a performance for the ages, carrying the Houston Rockets to a 96-90 victory over the Washington Bullets.

The story of this game is singular and staggering: Hakeem Olajuwon. The Dream was a force of nature, pouring in a colossal 42 points while hauling down 13 rebounds. He was not merely the best player on the floor; he was the entire Rockets' offensive ecosystem, operating with a devastating blend of power and finesse that the Bullets had no answer for. Every double-team was futile, every defensive scheme rendered obsolete by his brilliance.

While Olajuwon’s dominance was the headline, his supporting cast provided just enough supplementary scoring. Clyde Drexler chipped in 13 points, but the night belonged unequivocally to number 34. The Bullets, led by Chris Webber’s 20 points and 11 rebounds, fought valiantly. They stayed within striking distance, but each time they threatened, Olajuwon answered with an impossible fadeaway or a powerful post move.

The final margin of six points does little to illustrate Olajuwon’s sheer command. This was a historic, one-man tour de force—a 42-point masterpiece that reminded everyone in The Summit why "The Dream" remains one of the game's most unstoppable forces. The Rockets didn't just win a game; they witnessed a legend solidify his legacy.
